Award.AwardTitle: Storable, Thermally Activated Chemiluminescent and Fluorescent Dyes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry (MSN) Program supports Professor Bradley Smith of the University of Notre Dame to study chemiluminescent and fluorescent dyes that can be stored at zero degrees and then made to emit visible or near-infrared light by simply warming to body temperature. The research plan builds on the recent discovery of squaraine rotaxane endoperoxides, interlocked high energy molecules with a unique ability to emit light without chemical or electrical stimulus. The research objective is to improve fundamental understanding of the chemical process that produces the chemiluminescence and to use the new knowledge to design and prepare dyes with outstanding emission properties.

The work may enable a range of new biotechnology and nanotechnology applications that employ self-illuminating dyes for enhanced detection. The core training of research students is in organic chemistry and photochemistry with an emphasis on chemical structure, synthesis, and reaction mechanism. The broader impact is enhanced by a semi-formal interaction with a separate group of science business students who study entrepreneurship.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We invented a unique class of self-illuminating molecules called SREPs. They can be stored in a kitchen freezer and then made to glow by simply warming to body temperature. The self-illuminating property is called chemiluminescence and it is due to a chemical reaction. We made SREPs that can glow green, red, and near-infrared. We studied the mechanism for the chemiluminescence and used the knowledge to devise new methods to increase the brightness. We also discovered a new family of dyes called croconaine and croconaine rotaxanes and showed that we can shine laser light on them and create heating  without any bleaching of the dye. A US patent application has been submitted for this discovery which we think can be used to heat and kill cells associated with disease. We also produced an answer book for instructors who use the free internet workbook Organic Structure Elucidation. The workbook helps college students solve problems about the structures of organic molecules. The students who worked on this grant gained training and experience in synthetic chemistry, photochemistry, and multimedia presentation of results to expert and non-expert audiences. Some of the team members worked with science business students to prepare a patent application and related business plan.
